description: A practical course designed to help students succeed in the job/internship search and career development. Interviewing, networking, online tools, elevator pitch, career fair strategies, career center resources, company research techniques, resumes, cover letters, negotiating, follow-up messages. FALL [1]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Role of federal policy in supporting and promoting engineering and science for the benefit of the U.S. Ways engineering, science and public policy impact each other. Federal government involvement, policy making, federal budget, role of universities and national labs, national defense, homeland security, biomedical enterprise. SPRING [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Ship characteristics and types, including design and control, propulsion, hydrodynamic forces, stability, compartmentation, and electrical and auxiliary systems. Theory and design of steam, gas turbine, and nuclear propulsion. FALL. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Naval piloting procedures. Charts, visual and electronic aids, and theory and operation of magnetic and gyro compasses; inland and international rules of the nautical road. The celestial coordinate system, including spherical trigonometry and application for navigation at sea. Environmental influences on naval operations. SPRING. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Theory and employment of weapons systems, including the processes of detection, evaluation, threat analysis, weapon selection, delivery, guidance, and explosives. Fire control systems and major weapons types, including capabilities and limitations. Physical aspects of radar and underwater sound. Command, control, and communications and means of weapons system integration. SPRING. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Methods of tracking and intercepting at sea. Maritime maneuvering problems, formation tactics, and shipboard operations. Naval communications, ship behavior and maneuvering, and applied aspects of ship handling. Prerequisite: ES 3231. FALL. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
course_title: Energy and Sustainability - An Engineering Approach
full_title: ES3300 - Energy and Sustainability - An Engineering Approach
description: Uses basic understanding of mechanics, thermodynamics, and electrodynamics to describe primary and secondary energy generation and use. Emphasis on current applications, energy efficiency at both the source and demand sides, and future (near and long-term) energy scenarios. Various economic models are explored. Prerequisite: junior or senior standing. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Independent study under the direction of a faculty member with expertise in the area of study. [1-3 each semester]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Internship credit for work approved by the Associate Dean of the School of Engineering. A written scholarly project must be produced in the internship. Course must be taken P/F. May be repeated for credit; maximum of total 4 hours. No more than 2 hours may count toward degree requirements. FALL, SPRING, SUMMER. [1]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Technical elective courses of special current interest. No more than six semester hours of these courses may be credited to the student's record. Prerequisite: consent of instructor. FALL, SPRING. [1-3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Based on project specifications typically supplied by industrial sponsors or part of a student's immersive experience. Students are responsible for the formulation, execution, qualification, and documentation of a culminating capstone experience. Application of knowledge acquired from earlier coursework, both within and outside the engineering core area, along with realistic technical, managerial, and budgetary constraints using standard systems engineering methodologies and practices. Prerequisite: Senior standing. Corequisites: ES 4959, ENGM 3700. Fall. [1]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Based on project specifications typically supplied by industrial sponsors or part of a student's immersive experience. Students are responsible for the formulation, execution, qualification, and documentation of a culminating capstone experience. Application of knowledge acquired from earlier coursework, both within and outside the engineering core area, along with realistic technical, managerial, and budgetary constraints using standard systems engineering methodologies and practices. Prerequisite: ES 4950, Senior standing. SPRING. [3]

subject: Engineering Science
description: Elements of professional engineering practice. Professionalism, licensing, ethics and ethical issues, intellectual property, contracts, liability, risk, reliability and safety, interdisciplinary teams and team tools, codes, standards, professional organizations, careers, entrepreneurship, human factors, and industrial design. Prerequisite: Senior standing. FALL. [1]

subject: English
description: Topics vary. General Elective credit only. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: English
description: For students who need to improve their writing. Emphasis on writing skills, with some analysis of modern nonfiction writing. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: English
description: Individual instruction in writing fiction. Offered on a pass/fail basis only. Not open to students who have earned credit for ENGL 3851 section 07 without permission. Total credit hours for this course and ENGL 3851 section 7 will not exceed 1 credit hour. Credit hours reduced from most recent course taken (or from test or transfer credit) as appropriate. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: English
description: Individual instruction in writing poetry. Offered on a pass/fail basis only. Not open to students who have earned credit for ENGL 3851 section 07 without permission. Total credit hours for this course and ENGL 3851 section 7 will not exceed 1 credit hour. Credit hours reduced from most recent course taken (or from test or transfer credit) as appropriate. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: English
description: Independent learning and inquiry in an environment in which students can express knowledge and defend opinions through intensive class discussion, oral presentations, and written expression. May be repeated for credit once if there is no duplication of topic, but students may earn only up to 3 credits in any 1111 course per semester of enrollment. [3; maximum of 6 credits total for all semesters of 1111] (AXLE credit category varies by section)

subject: English
description: Diverse narratives and themes in influential short stories and novels; fiction's role in cultural and personal identity; techniques for analysis. Each section will have a specific theme—see English Departmental Course Descriptions. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Close study of representative plays of the major periods and of the main formal categories (tragedy, comedy) and written explication of these forms. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Close reading and writing in a variety of genres drawn from several periods. Productive dialogue, persuasive argument, and effective prose style. Offered on a graded basis only. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Close study and criticism of poems. The nature of poetry, and the process of literary explication. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
course_title: Introduction to Literary and Cultural Analysis
full_title: ENGL1260W - Introduction to Literary and Cultural Analysis
description: Analysis of a range of texts in social, political, and aesthetic contexts. Interdisciplinary study of cultural forms as diverse as poetry, advertisement, and film. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Selected critical approaches to literature. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL1272 - Literature and Structures of Society
description: How the structures of literature illuminate or conceal the structure of society. Emphasis on diverse, often contradictory perspectives that challenge and reshape conventional views; signifying potential of objects; literature's influence on societal transformation. Each section has its own theme—see English Departmental Course Descriptions. [3] (CORE A, B) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Key ethical questions raised by literature. How literature influences and challenges ethical norms; paradigms of judgment; historical contexts and power dynamics. Each section has its own theme—see English Departmental Course Descriptions. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, E) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Introduction to the art of writing prose fiction. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Introduction to writing creative nonfiction. [3] (HCA) (CORE: A) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Introduction to the art of writing poetry. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Writing in three different creative modes: poetry, short story, and creative nonfiction. The elements of imaginative writing while cultivating one's own voice. [3] (CORE A) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: A writing course including the analysis of essays from a variety of disciplines. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Fundamentals of literary study: close reading; analytic writing; historical context; abstract reasoning in theory; creative expression. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Write compelling stories while exploring different genres and traditions across cultures and media. Use fiction to persuade, influence, and connect with others.  [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: A practical introduction to the elements of writing stories. Develop reading skills by analyzing a range of narratives and styles and enhance your own creative expression by drafting original stories. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: A hands-on, enriching introduction to writing poetry. Appreciation for forms, rhythms, and imagery as you analyze diverse poems and cultivate your own poetic voice. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Prepare for and participate in the November 'National Novel Writing Month' challenge. From concept to completion, bringing  fictional world to life. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: The dynamic, immersive craft of graphic novels—no drawing skills required. Developing sequential narrative art through engaging works like those of Marjane Satrapi and Alison Bechdel. Blending words and images to create graphic fiction or nonfiction. Serves as repeat credit for ENGL 1111 section 63 offered Fall 2023. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: A practical introduction to shaping public opinion and knowledge through popular news media. Study contemporary forms of journalism and their persuasive techniques and craft compelling, accurate narratives that engage a broad audience. [3] (CORE A, B) (LE HFA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL2242 - Shakespeare for the Contemporary Age
description: Shakespeare’s impact through recent performances, adaptations, and rewritings. His works’ relevance in contemporary settings and their influence on modern media. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Evolution of love in literature from Antiquity to Early Modernity. Diverse portrayals, including spiritual and erotic, across genres of epic, lyric, and drama. Examine love’s impact on subjectivity, identity, and social order and critique through Lucretius, Ovid, Virgil, and Renaissance authors. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL2248 - The Curious Pursuit of Knowledge
description: The transformation of curiosity from vice to virtue during the Scientific Revolution. Early modern scientific concepts in dialogue with literary texts by Donne, Marlowe, Shakespeare, and others. The interaction between experimental science and literature, and interplay among evidence, plausibility, and narrative. How the pioneers of science communicated their discoveries to skeptical audiences. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: The monstrous in literature and film, ranging from the medieval to the contemporary across a variety of genres. The role of the monstrous in fashioning and challenging the boundaries of the human. Serves as repeat credit for ENGL 1111 section 66 offered Spring 2024. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Afro-futurist and fantasy narratives that explore alternate realities and imagine the future of humanity in relation to non-humans. Experiments with literary forms that confront societal, technological, and ethical dilemmas. Authors include Octavia Butler, Ursula Le Guin, Nnedi Okorafor, and Jeff Vandermeer. [3] (CORE C, E) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: What makes a body human, and what rights do human bodies have? Examining these questions in novels like The Handmaid’s Tale, Never Let Me Go, and The Hunger Games. Why fiction matters to bodies now and in the future. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Caribbean poetry in a postcolonial context. Poets to include Edward Kamau Brathwaite, Derek Walcott, Dionne Brand, and others. Responses to colonial legacies, migration, race, and the politics of English. Poetry’s role in narrating and reimagining historical and contemporary realities. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
course_title: Storytelling in American Verse: Frost to Dove
full_title: ENGL2254 - Storytelling in American Verse: Frost to Dove
description: Narrative verse in American poetry. Innovations by Robert Frost, Robinson Jeffers, Gwendolyn Brooks, and Rita Dove as they respond to historical events such as the Great Depression, World Wars, migrations, and the Civil Rights movement. Lyricism and epic; deploying and breaking form. Serves as repeat credit for ENGL 1111 section 25 offered Fall 2023. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL2255 - Rise of the American Novel
description: Early foundations of the American novel through the post-Civil War period. How authors like Lydia Maria Child and Charles Brockden Brown invented genres such as American Gothic and Historical Romance and addressed crises like Indian Removal and slavery. Novels that shaped America's collective imagination and envisioned alternative histories and futures. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Cultures of seashores and ocean explored through autobiography, fiction, poetry, and art. The transformations of identity, body, and imagination provoked by life at sea. Literary and artistic responses to oceanic challenges—from threats to the Great Barrier Reef to the Pacific’s vast plastic gyres. Featured works include Coleridge’s 'Rime of the Ancient Mariner,' and Turner’s sea-themed paintings. [3] (CORE A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Ecological crises and modes of environmental thinking in literature and other media. Historical role of representation in reinforcing or challenging environmental ideologies. The interplay between social conflict and climate change; influence of gender, race, and class on environmental narratives. Methodological approaches such as ecocriticism, environmental justice, and activism provide a broad perspective. [3] (CORE A) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Representation of Asian Americans and their integral roles in American culture and imagination. Diverse histories of Asian American ethnic groups; themes of identity, immigration, and resistance across fiction, poetry, films, games, and other cultural forms. Serves as repeat credit for ENGL 1111 section 03 offered Spring 2024. [3] (P) (CORE B, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Beginning with Morrison's two early novels, The Bluest Eye and Song of Solomon, and ending with her Nobel-prize winning work, Beloved.  Race, gender, class, and sexuality; geography and migration; history, trauma, and memory; kinship and community; nation and region; oppression and freedom; language and the artist's role. Serves as repeat credit for ENGL 1111-16. [3] (P) (CORE: A, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: May be repeated for credit if there is no duplication in topic. [3] (No Axle Credit) (CORE: C, E) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: May be repeated for credit if there is no duplication in topic. [3] (HCA) (CORE: C, E) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Selections from British literature with attention to contexts and literary periods. From the beginnings to 1660. Provides a broad background for more specialized courses and is especially useful for students considering advanced studies in literature. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, B) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Selections from British literature with attention to contexts and literary periods. From 1660 to the present. Provides a broad background for more specialized courses and is especially useful for students considering advanced studies in literature. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Selections from the entire body of American literature with attention to contexts and literary periods. Provides a broad background for more specialized courses and is especially useful for students considering advanced studies in literature. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2316W. [3] (US) (CORE B, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Selections from the entire body of American literature with attention to contexts and literary periods. Provides a broad background for more specialized courses and is especially useful for students considering advanced studies in literature. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2316. [3] (US)

subject: English
description: Great Books from the points of view of literary expression and changing ideologies: Classical Greece through the Renaissance. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2318W. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Great Books from the points of view of literary expression and changing ideologies: Classical Greece through the Renaissance. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2318. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Great Books from the points of view of literary expression and changing ideologies: The 17th century to the contemporary period. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2319W. [3] (HCA) (CORE B, C) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: Great Books from the points of view of literary expression and changing ideologies: The 17th century to the contemporary period. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2319. [3] (HCA) (LE HFA)

subject: English
description: The works of Southern writers from Captain Smith to the present. Topics such as the Plantation Myth, slavery and civil war, Agrarianism, and "post-southernism." Authors may include Poe, Twain, Cable, Faulkner, Welty, Percy, Wright. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Interdisciplinary study of human beings' relationship to the environment. Literary, artistic, historical, and philosophical perspectives. Cultural understandings of the environment. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Interdisciplinary study of human beings' relationship to the environment. Literary, artistic, historical, and philosophical perspectives. Cultural understandings of the environment. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL2740 - Topics in Literature and Philosophy
description: Literary, philosophical, and cultural texts on varied philosophical topics. May be repeated for credit if there is no duplication in topic. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course per semester. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
full_title: ENGL2740W - Topics in Literature and Philosophy

description: Diverse range of literary, philosophical, cultural, and political texts. May be repeated for credit if there is no duplication in topic. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course per semester. [3] (HCA)

subject: English
description: Topic chosen by the instructor. Prerequisite: 2200. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: English
description: No description available

subject: English
description: No description available

subject: English Education
description: Explores characteristics of good literature for children ages birth to 12, authors and illustrators of the genre, and issues in the area of children's literature. [3]

subject: English Education
description: Overview of language learning, emphasizing ages 3 - 8 and the role of teachers and parents in fostering growth. Variability associated with culture, income, home language and individual child characteristics is examined from developmental and sociolinguistic perspectives. Students examine language use and teaching as part of an 8 hour practicum in an early childhood classroom. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Language Study in the Secondary Classroom
full_title: ENED3310 - Language Study in the Secondary Classroom
description: Investigates various methods of approaching grammar, vocabulary spelling, semantics, and bi-dialectism in the English classroom. For teachers and prospective teachers of middle school and high school English. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Untapped Potential: The Power of Books for Fostering Language and Learning
full_title: ENED3320 - Untapped Potential: The Power of Books for Fostering Language and Learning
description: This course fosters an understanding of the importance of developing oral language and thinking skills in read alouds and develops students' competence in implementing instructional strategies in their work with children and families. Course content explores historical trends and lines of inquiry in storybook reading research over the past four decades and engages students in critical conversations about the extent to which current pedagogical practices reflect or rebuff research recommendations. The course explores book selection, vocabulary development, inferential reasoning, the use of repeated readings, responding to students' questions and confusions, and crafting high-cognitive demand discussions in narratives read aloud to children from Pre-K through fourth grade. The roles of adults and approaches to sharing books with children are explored from developmental and cultural perspectives. Content includes careful study and discussion of narrative picture books, criteria for identifying high-quality literature, and extracting worthy story themes with an aim toward developing skill in using books that embody humanizing pedagogies and diverse perspectives. Assignments involve the application of course content to teacher observations, the implementation of multiple readings in embedded fieldwork experiences, book studies, and the opportunities for special projects related to nuanced interest areas. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Reading and Learning with Print and New Media
full_title: ENED3340 - Reading and Learning with Print and New Media
description: Studies print and technology-based approaches to improving reading and content area learning in grades 6-12 with a special emphasis on diverse learners and struggling readers. Drawing on research-based practice, students learn to design, enact, and assess effective reading and literacy instruction. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Literature, Popular Culture, and New Media
full_title: ENED3350 - Literature, Popular Culture, and New Media
description: Examines a wide range of multigenre, multimodal, and digital texts appropriate for readers of middle school and high school age. Considers the influence of popular culture and digital technologies on young adult literature. Includes materials and texts for readers of various ability levels. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Literature, Pop Culture, and New Media
full_title: ENED3357 - Literature, Pop Culture, and New Media
description: Considers the influence of popular culture and digital technologies on young adult literature and the ways in which societal critique, role of the media, and negotiating identity categories play out in those texts. Examines a wide range of Multigenre, multimodal, and digital fiction focused on various themes such as Real and Imagined Worlds: Gaming and Technology in Texts, Vampires, Zombies, Werewolves and Monsters: Imagining the Other, ans Who am I? Race, Class, Gender, and Sexual Identity in Literature. [3]

subject: English Education
course_title: Teaching Literature and New Media in the Secondary School
full_title: ENED3370 - Teaching Literature and New Media in the Secondary School
description: Students study how pedagogy might be developed that connects traditional literature instruction with media popular cultural media. Methods and theories for reading and teaching short stories, poetry, and novels are juxtaposed and interwoven with methods and theories for reading and teaching web sites, comics, film, and other media. Prerequisite: EDUC 3310 or consent of instructor. Corequisite: ENED 3371. [3]

subject: English Education
description: Observation, participation, and teaching in middle school and secondary school settings. Corequisite: ENED 3370. [3]

subject: English Education
full_title: ENED3380 - Teaching Writing in Secondary Schools
description: Designed to encourage student teachers to examine the complexities of teaching writing in middle and high school settings and to develop a theoretically sound methodology that will allow them to design meaningful, engaging, and thoughtful writing instruction. [3]

subject: English Education
full_title: ENED3400 - Harry Potter and Children's Literature
description: Students will examine British Literature related to J.K. Rowling's novels. Students will be asked to relate what they learn from other children's literature to the characters, plot, and themes of the Harry Potter novels as well as the opportunity to perform a variety of critical analyses of a social/cultural phenomena with progressive young adult literature. Additionally, students will explore the film versions of all novels discussed to analyze and critique the adaptations. This is a weekend course that includes week-long travel to the United Kingdom where students will engage in the stories in an experiential journey of local UK sites, studios, and museums. [3]

subject: English Education
description: Historical events, issues, and movements are often explored in literature for children and adolescents. The literature helps make history come alive. This class will focus on stories relating to the Civil Rights Movement that led to social transformation the United States. In this weekend course, students will explore books written for children/young adults, discuss specific episodes of the Movement where youth had great impact, and visit libraries, museums, and related sites. [3]

subject: English Education
full_title: ENED3850 - Independent Study in English Education
description: Semi-independent study on selected topics in English education. Consent of supervising instructor required. May be repeated. [1-3]

subject: English Education
full_title: ENED3890 - Special Topics in English Education
description: Exploration of special topics related to English education. May be repeated with change of topic. [1-3]

subject: English Education
description: Seminar to accompany EDUC 4953. A $300.00 Teacher Performance Assessment fee is associated with this course. [3]

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students. Musicians participate in orchestra, wind ensembles, and/or a variety of smaller ensembles on a rotational basis through the course of the semester. Performances include symphonic repertoire from the Classical and Romantic periods as well as standard and new repertoire from Baroque to Contemporary. At least three formal concerts are presented each semester. [1] Fountain, Verrier.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students regardless of major. This choral ensemble performs a wide variety of choral music spanning Renaissance to contemporary music, and often combines with the Vanderbilt Symphony Orchestra on large works. At least two formal concerts per semester. [1] Biddlecombe.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students. Performance material chosen from all forms of lyric theatre: standard operatic repertoire, operetta, and American musical theatre. At least one production is presented. FALL. [1] Shay.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all members of the Vanderbilt community, this course provides a laboratory and performance experience drawing on Caribbean steel drums/pans with emphasis on the music and dance repertories of the island of Trinidad. Lecture-demonstrations and rehearsals in one weekly two-hour session. At least one public performance each semester. No previous experience required. [1] Britain.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all members of the Vanderbilt community, this course provides a laboratory and performance experience drawing on Caribbean steel drums/pans with emphasis on the music and dance repertories of the island of Trinidad. Lecture-demonstrations and rehearsals in one weekly two-hour session. At least one public performance each semester. Ability to read musical notation required. [1] Britain.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all members of the Vanderbilt community, this course provides a laboratory and performance experience drawing on Caribbean steel drums/pans with emphasis on the music and dance repertories of the island of Trinidad. Lecture-demonstrations and rehearsals in one weekly two-hour session. At least one public performance each semester. Ability to read musical notation required. Prerequisite: MUSE 1200 or 1210. [1] Britain.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all members of the Vanderbilt community, this course provides a laboratory and performance experience drawing on traditional African musical instruments (drums, percussion, winds) with an emphasis on West African (Ghana) and East African (Uganda) music and dance repertories. Lecture-demonstrations and rehearsals in one weekly two-hour session. At least one public performance each semester. No previous experience required. [1] Ahima.

subject: Ensembles
description: Advanced laboratory and performance experience drawing on traditional African musical instruments (drums, percussion, winds) with an emphasis on West African (Ghana) and East African (Uganda) music and dance repertories. Lecture-demonstrations and rehearsals in one weekly two-hour session. At least one public performance each semester. Prerequisite MUSE 1230 or permission from the instructor. [1]

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students, this ensemble performs both traditional and modern jazz styles, including dance band, swing, contemporary, and charts currently under development. Improvisation, jazz timbres, and other idiomatic concepts explored through lecture-demonstration and performance. At least one concert is presented each semester. Co-requisite: JAZZ 1000. [1] Middagh

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students. Provides focused laboratory training for performance of composed and improvised small combo jazz traditions. Discussion and application of techniques associated with solo, sectional, and ensemble performance in jazz. At least one concert is presented each semester. Co-requisite: JAZZ 1000. [1]

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students; ensemble is limited to 12 voices, plus rhythm section. Repertoire includes scat, contemporary, and standard jazz. On- and off-campus performances throughout the semester. [1] Watson Utterstrom

subject: Ensembles
course_title: Special Ensemble in Jazz and Global Music
full_title: MUSE1340 - Special Ensemble in Jazz and Global Music
description: Annually rotating ensemble focused on a particular musical style representative of jazz or global music traditions. Open to all undergraduates. Co-requisite: JAZZ 1000. [1]

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by audition to all Vanderbilt students, this select 36-40 voice choral ensemble performs music in a variety of styles. At least two formal concerts each semester. [1] Biddlecombe.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all Vanderbilt students by audition or upon recommendation of the private instructor. Size of ensembles may vary. One hour weekly coaching. Two hours of additional rehearsal each week. Performance faculty. [1.0]

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to percussion majors and minors. Size of ensembles will vary. One hour weekly coaching and two hours of additional rehearsal (independent of coaching) expected each week. [¬Ω or 1] Jung.

subject: Ensembles
course_title: Chamber Music: Sonata Class for Strings and Piano
full_title: MUSE2230 - Chamber Music: Sonata Class for Strings and Piano
description: One hour weekly class for performance and study of string (violin, viola, cello, bass) and piano sonatas from the standard repertoire, baroque through modern, with each sonata duo receiving thirty minutes of coaching within the class time. Performance of complete sonata during the last class of the semester. Two hours of additional rehearsal each week. Open by consent of instructor. [1] Dorfman, Plummer.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by consent of instructor. One hour of coaching and at least two hours of additional rehearsal each week. Variable credit: [0.5-2] Kochanowski.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open to all Vanderbilt students with experience on Baroque instruments or upon recommendation of the private instructor. Size of ensembles may vary. Students will receive one hour of coaching and are expected to rehearse at least two additional hours each week. [0.5-1]

subject: Ensembles
full_title: MUSE2280 - Chamber Music: Contemporary Music Ensemble
description: Open to all Vanderbilt students by audition, this ensemble will perform instrumental and vocal chamber works of the modern and contemporary periods. Includes weekly coaching and two required hours of additional rehearsal (independent of coaching) each week. [1]

subject: Ensembles
description: Basic ensemble techniques in vocal and instrumental collaboration, including orchestral reductions, instrumental repertoire, recitatives/arias, songs, and introduction to diction/translation of song texts. Both group and individual coaching. Open to B.Mus. and B.Mus.Arts piano majors or by consent of instructor. [1]

subject: Ensembles
description: Introduces pianists to collaboration with instrumentalists. Weekly coaching with piano instructor and 5 hours practice/rehearsal per week. Standard instrumental repertoire will be assigned. Open by consent of instructor. [Variable credit: ¬Ω, 1, or 2 each semester] Dorfman, Nies, Melissa Rose.

subject: Ensembles
description: Introduces pianists to collaboration with singers. Weekly coaching with piano instructor and 5 hours practice/rehearsal per week. Focus on standard art song and opera repertoire. Open by consent of instructor. [Variable credit: 1-2 each semester] Dorfman, Nies, Melissa Rose.

subject: Ensembles
description: Open by consent of the instructor. One hour weekly coaching for vocal/instrumental duos or ensembles, including singer/piano duos. Two hours of additional rehearsal each week. Variable credit: [0.5-2] Dorfman, Melissa Rose.

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Introduction to environmental analyses (physical/chemical and biological) for assessing the level of contamination in air, soil, and water and for compliance monitoring.  Sample planning/handling/preservation and sampling technique, quality assurance/quality control requirements. Includes uncertainty, analysis and interpretation of data. Corequisite: ENVE 3600. FALL. [1].

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Evaluation of unit processes and materials durability. Characterization of water, soil, and recycled materials and wastes to determine environmental compliance and suitability for use. Utilization of the campus and local community as a “living laboratory”.  Use of advanced instrumentation-based measurement techniques of appropriate parameters. Includes hands-on sample collection, handling, testing and data analysis. Prerequisite: ENVE 3200. SPRING. [2].

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Parameters affecting environmental quality, including air and water pollutants; treatment techniques to achieve drinking water quality or permit safe discharge to the environment. Sustainability. Contaminant transport and interactions of contaminants with the environment. Risk assessment and governmental regulations covering air, water, solid and hazardous wastes. Residuals management including hazardous and solid waste. Prerequisite: CHEM 1601, PHYS 1601, MATH 2420. FALL. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Quantitative investigation of the role of adequate and renewable resources for continual economic development. Past and present resource challenges, influences of indigenous, national, and international cultures, land use practices, social policy, and economic strategies on infrastructure development. Future challenges posed by climate change, and how market- and government-based policies may be applied in conditions of uncertainty to encourage sustainable development. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Development of an organization-wide risk management program for protecting human health, the environment and business continuity. Focus on defining an all-hazards risk management process and program implementation, performing risk assessments, determining and selecting appropriate risk reduction strategies, and influencing risk management decisions internally and externally. Applications drawn from natural disasters, man-made accidents and intentional acts. Prerequisite: Senior standing. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Theoretical aspects of physical, organic, and inorganic chemistry applied to environmental engineering. Estimation of chemical parameters based on thermodynamic and structural activity relationships, pH as a master variable, equilibrium processes in the environment, including the carbonate system, metal complexation and precipitation. Prerequisite: CHEM 1601. FALL. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
course_title: Environmental Thermodynamics, Kinetics, and Mass Transfer
full_title: ENVE4605 - Environmental Thermodynamics, Kinetics, and Mass Transfer
description: Examination of fundamental environmental processes and phenomena. Uses of equilibrium phenomena, process rate and mass transport phenomena to solve a broad range of environmental problems. Prerequisite: CHEM 1602, MATH 2420, ENVE 3600. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
full_title: ENVE4610 - Biological Processes in Environmental Systems
description: Principles of biology and their application to wastewater treatment processes with emphasis on microbial ecology, bioenergetics, and the role of chemical structure in biodegradability. Utilization kinetics of inhibitory and non-inhibitory organic compounds. Biological process analysis and design (aerobic and anaerobic) for municipal and industrial wastewaters, using a mass balance approach. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Design and conduct of environmental assessments to evaluate risks posed by infrastructure systems or environmental contamination. Impact analyses for sources, infrastructure modifications, due diligence environmental audits, and contaminated site remedial investigations. Prerequisite: Senior standing. FALL. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Acquisition and interpretation of environmental data. Principles of chemical measurement, sample collection and sample program design; laboratory safety and good laboratory practices; analytical instrumentation and methods; quality assurance and quality control; and statistical interpretation of data. Hands-on experience through demonstrations featuring state-of-the-art analytical instrumentation. Prerequisite: CE 3600, ENVE 4600. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Fundamentals and applications of separations processes relevant to water and wastewater treatment and other environmental systems. Topics include coagulation/flocculation, sedimentation, granular filtration; advanced separation processes such as various membrane processes, absorption, ion exchange, thermally driven separations, and electrically driven separations including electrodialysis and capacitive deionization. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Scientific, technological, philosophical, and social issues surrounding approaches to carbon-based energy and alternative energy resources, management of carbon through sequestration, supplying and treating water for agriculture, communities, and industry, and changing climate impacts on regional distribution of water resources. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Development of fundamental bases of hydrological processes. Land-atmosphere processes, surface-water flows, soil moisture dynamics, and groundwater flows. Exposition of physical principles, their embodiment in mathematical models, and their use in interpreting observations in the field and laboratory. Prerequisites: CE 3700 or ME 3224 or ChBE 3300 or EES 4550. FALL. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: The hydrologic cycle, study of precipitation, evapotranspiration, hydrometeorology, stream flow, flood flow, flood routing, storm sewer design, detention basin design, and water quality. Prerequisite: CE 3700, CE 3705. FALL. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: The occurrence and flow of ground water. Basic concepts of the effects of varying permeability and capillarity on seepage flow. Flow toward wells, through dikes, and beneath dams. Prerequisite: MATH 2420, CE 3700. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Analysis of physical, chemical, biological, and physiological contaminants in streams, lakes, and estuaries, and surface water/groundwater interfaces. Analytical and numerical modeling techniques. One- and two-dimension computer simulation of surface water quality. Prerequisite: ENVE 4605. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: The nuclear fuel cycle and environmental and societal impacts associated with its traditional implementation. Technical and programmatic challenges associated with fuel production, and waste management including processing, storage, transportation, decontamination, decommissioning, and environmental restoration. Technologies and approaches for reducing impacts of the nuclear fuel cycle. Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing. SPRING. [3]

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Capstone design for environmental engineers. Project conception, design, economic evaluations, safety, reliability, ethics, social and environmental impact, licensure, and government regulations. Projects may be interdisciplinary, competition-oriented, or traditional environmental engineering projects. Prerequisite: ENVE 3600. FALL [1].

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Continuation of ENVE 4950. Course includes an oral presentation and the submission of a final design report. Prerequisite: ENVE 4950. SPRING. [2].

subject: Environmental Engineering
description: Elements of professional engineering practice. Professionalism, licensing, ethics and ethical issues, diversity equity and inclusion, intellectual property, contracts, liability, risk, reliability and safety, interdisciplinary teams and team tools, codes, standards, professional organizations, careers, entrepreneurship, human factors, and industrial design. Prerequisite: senior standing. Corequisite: ENVE 4950. FALL. [1].

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Topics vary. General Elective credit only. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Scholarship from across the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities.  History and science of climate change;, the cultural and political-economic systems that shape climate injustice. Challenges and possible solutions to the climate crisis.  [3] (P)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
full_title: ENVS2323 - NGOs, Society, and Climate Change
description: (Formerly listed as 3301) Nonprofits as complex and diverse actors engaged in climate mitigation, climate adaptation, policy, and energy justice. Logics of nonprofit organizations; grant-writing. Perspectives and insights from sociology, political science, and nonprofit studies. Serves as repeat credit for SOC 3319 prior to Fall 2025, or SOC 2323 onward. [3] (SBS)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Origins and social dynamics of movements that have sought to mitigate, resist, or deny climate change. Climate change inequities and vulnerabilities of poor peoples and nations. Impacts on processes of global social change. Serves as repeat credit for SOC 3314. [3] (SBS) (CORE A, B) (LE SBS)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Independent research on issues of theoretical and/or practical relevance to understanding and addressing climate & environmental change. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course each semester. May be repeated for a total of 6 credits.  [1-6] (No AXLE credit).

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
full_title: ENVS4101 - Society and the Environment Capstone
description: The relationship between society and the environment. Sustainability, adaptation, climate science, and policy. Open only to junior and senior ENVS minors. [3] (SBS)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
full_title: ENVS4101W - Society and the Environment Capstone
description: The relationship between society and the environment. Sustainability, adaptation, climate science, and policy. Open only to junior and senior ENVS minors. Repeat credit for students who have completed ENVS 4101. [3] (SBS)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit more than once if there is no duplication in topic. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course each semester. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: Environmental and Sustainability Studies
description: Research and writing supervised by program faculty. Students are expected to take 3 credits in the fall and 3 credits in the spring term. Open only to honors candidates. Prerequisite or corequisite: completion of methods and practices requirement for the Climate Studies major. [3; maximum of 9 credits total for all semesters of 4981] [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: Topics vary. General Elective credit only. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: An interdisciplinary survey of European society, culture, and politics since 1900. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
full_title: EUS2202 - European Politics and EU Institutions
description: The European project, its institutional structure, and political dynamics. European Parliament, Commission, Council, Court of Justice. Elections, parties, policies, and governance. Discussion of the legislative process, democracy and illiberalism, border politics, defense mechanisms, environmentalism, economics, memory culture, and education. [3] (INT) (CORE B, C) (LE HFA)

subject: European Studies
description: European identity from ancient ideals to its reality as the European Union. Emphasis on Europe as cultural construct and definable space. Historical, political, religious, philosophical, and cultural movements for Europe's claim to legitimacy. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
description: The cultural evolution from 1500s to the present. Cultural production in the fine arts, architecture, and literature as a result of trade and the concentration of political power. Global perspective on the impact of Europe. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Conspiracy Theories and Rumors in European and U.S. History
full_title: EUS2208 - Conspiracy Theories and Rumors in European and U.S. History
description: From 1600 to the present. Jesuits, Jews, and the Illuminati. The American and French Revolutions, McCarthyism, UFOs, and New World Order theories. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
description: Twentieth-century European aesthetic, political, and social imagination from Expressionism and Dadaism to Fluxus and Happenings. Connection between aesthetics and capitalism. Impact of World Wars on art and literature, gender roles, and 'exoticism'. Art as an institution and literature as performance. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Revolutions and Post-Communisms in Eastern Europe and Eurasia, 1981-2010
full_title: EUS2212 - Revolutions and Post-Communisms in Eastern Europe and Eurasia, 1981-2010
description: Life in the Soviet Imperium. Revolutions of 1989 in Eastern Europe. Disintegration of the U.S.S.R., 1989-1991. Challenges of neoliberal transitions to free-market democracies. Post-socialist culture. Ecology and environmentalism; globalization; gender; religion and ideology; mass media; violence; ethno-nationalism; and authoritarianism. Taught in English. Serves as repeat credit for students who have earned credit for HIST 2212, EUS 2212 or RUSS 2810/5810. [3] (P)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Introduction to European Intellectual Traditions: Ancient and Medieval
full_title: EUS2213 - Introduction to European Intellectual Traditions: Ancient and Medieval
description: Philosophical, religious, and literary foundations. Texts by Homer, Virgil, Augustine, and Dante together with background from the Bible. [3] (HCA)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Introduction to European Intellectual Traditions: Renaissance and Modernity
full_title: EUS2214 - Introduction to European Intellectual Traditions: Renaissance and Modernity
description: Great books of western intellectual traditions through Renaissance to Modernity. Science, technology, religion, imagination, and human individuality. Texts by Dante, Shakespeare, Cervantes, and Goethe. [3] (HCA) (CORE B, C) (LE HFA)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Religion and Politics in Modern Europe, 1648-Present
full_title: EUS2220 - Religion and Politics in Modern Europe, 1648-Present
description: Toleration in the Enlightenment; the French Revolution; antisemitism; genocide; secularism and political Islam. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Right-wing Populist Parties: Populism in Europe and Beyond
full_title: EUS2222 - Right-wing Populist Parties: Populism in Europe and Beyond
description: Theoretical and historical concepts of populism. Case studies of populist parties in France, Italy, the Netherlands, Austria, Germany, Poland, and Hungary. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: The Flight of Vulnerable Migrants to Europe
full_title: EUS2228 - The Flight of Vulnerable Migrants to Europe
description: Exploration of refugees' flight from persecution, and their search for protection in Europe. International Refugee Law; "refugee-creating" events in Africa and the Middle East. Geographic pathways and legal processes followed by those who have sought protection. Depictions of their plight in film, music, literature, and the visual arts. [3] (INT) (CORE C, E) (LE HFA)

subject: European Studies
course_title: European History and Culture Through Immersive Gaming
full_title: EUS2230W - European History and Culture Through Immersive Gaming
description: Experiential, game-based study of key historical moments in European history using "Reacting to the Past" (RTP) pedagogy for engaged classroom learning. Offered on a graded basis only. Serves as repeat credit for RPW 3890W-01 Revolutions, offered spring 2023. [3] (HCA)

subject: European Studies
description: Topics of special interest on modern European culture or society. May be repeated for credit when topics vary. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: The history, politics, society, or culture of important European cities. Content varies according to location and disciplinary focus. The course is taught during the May Session in Europe with the cities themselves complementing daily lectures and site visits. Course requirements include preliminary work on campus, a research paper, and one or more examinations. May be repeated for credit in different cities. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: Pursuing Utopia: Social Justice & Romanticism in the Alps
full_title: EUS2800 - Pursuing Utopia: Social Justice & Romanticism in the Alps
description: Social justice and literary experiments of writers who sought alternative approaches to art and society in the 'neutral' Alpine settings of Europe. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
course_title: The European Refugee Experience: From Populism to Covid-19
full_title: EUS3333 - The European Refugee Experience: From Populism to Covid-19
description: Journey of refugees towards protection in Europe; overview of international refugee law. Myriad 'refugee-creating' events, intermediaries, and challenges. [3] (INT)

subject: European Studies
description: Independent readings and/or research on approved topics relating to modern European society and culture. [Variable credit: 1-3 each semester, maximum of 6 hours in 3850 and 3851 combined] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: Independent readings and/or research on approved topics relating to modern European society and culture. [Variable credit: 1-3 each semester, maximum of 6 hours in 3850 and 3851 combined] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: Supervised readings, joint discussions, and independent research on a modern European topic to be selected in consultation with the director of European Studies. Open only to juniors and seniors. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: European Studies
description: Open only to seniors who have been admitted to the European Studies departmental honors program. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: Foreign Language Education
course_title: Independent Study in Foreign Language Education
full_title: FLED3850 - Independent Study in Foreign Language Education
description: Semi-independent study on selected topics in foreign language education. May be repeated. Consent of instructor required. [1-3]

subject: French
description: Topics vary. General Elective credit only. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
course_title: Introduction to French in the World
full_title: FREN1101 - Introduction to French in the World
description: Reading, writing, speaking, and listening through an exploration of the French-speaking world. For students who have studied little or no French. No credit for students who have earned credit for a more advanced French language course. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
course_title: Introduction to French in the World
full_title: FREN1102 - Introduction to French in the World
description: Continuation of 1101. Study of the language through an exploration of the French-speaking world. No credit for students who have earned credit for a more advanced French language course. [3] (INT)

subject: French
course_title: Accelerated Introduction to French in the World
full_title: FREN1103 - Accelerated Introduction to French in the World
description: Intensive course for students who have studied one to three years of French. No credit for students who have earned credit for 1101, 1102, or a more advanced French language course. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Independent learning and inquiry in an environment in which students can express knowledge and defend opinions through intensive class discussion, oral presentations, and written expression. May be repeated for credit once if there is no duplication of topic, but students may earn only up to 3 credits in any 1111 course per semester of enrollment. [3; maximum of 6 credits total for all semesters of 1111] (AXLE credit category varies by section)

subject: French
full_title: FREN2203 - Intermediate French Language and Cultures
description: French and Francophone cultures through readings, film, and discussion. Designed for students who have completed elementary-level French. No credit for students who have earned credit for a more advanced French language course. Prerequisite: 1102 or 1103. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Prerequisite: 2203 or three semesters of French or equivalent, i.e. departmental placement score above 420. No credit for students who have earned credit for a more advanced French language course. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Methodical comparison of French and English sounds. Correct formation of French sounds; oral exercises and aural training. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Emphasis on idiomatic usage and strategies for oral communication. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (P) (CORE LA)

subject: French
course_title: Great French and Francophone Works in English Translation
full_title: FREN2700 - Great French and Francophone Works in English Translation
description: Middle Ages to modernity. Emergence of the modern nation-state and liberal ideals of the eighteenth-century Enlightenment; French Revolution and modernist movements in the arts. Troubadours, Romance of Rose, Racine, Voltaire, Diderot, Rousseau, Hugo, Cézanne, Flaubert, Césaire, Condé, Djebar, Sembéne. [3] (INT)

subject: French
course_title: Texts and Contexts: Middle Ages to the Enlightenment
full_title: FREN3001 - Texts and Contexts: Middle Ages to the Enlightenment
description: Literary works from 500 to 1800 in historical context. Analysis and discussion of a variety of texts (novels, plays, poems and non-fiction) as well as social and cultural history. Not open to students who have earned credit for 3101. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
course_title: Texts and Contexts: Revolution to the Present
full_title: FREN3002 - Texts and Contexts: Revolution to the Present
description: French and Francophone literature and art from 1800 to the present in a historical context. Great works by authors such as Hugo, Zola, Baudelaire, Colette, Césaire, Camus, Sartre, Beauvoir, Ernaux, Chedid, and Slimani. Study of novels, poems, plays, and films through cultural movements like Romanticism, Naturalism, Symbolism, Surrealism, and Existentialism. Prerequisite: FREN 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Specialized vocabulary of business terms, business letters, and exercises in comprehension and translation. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Global healthcare language and cultures in the francophone world. Comparisons of healthcare systems.  Exploration of global health NGOs.   Advanced linguistic and cultural tools for the study of human anatomy, and chronic and common diseases (prevention, detection, symptoms and diagnostic tests, treatment, and follow-up).   Case studies and simulations. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: A systematic review with particular attention to morphology and syntax. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT)

subject: French
course_title: French for Law and Diplomacy in a Global Context
full_title: FREN3114 - French for Law and Diplomacy in a Global Context
description: Structural differences between the legal systems of the United States and the Francophone world. Governmental structures, jurisprudence, international governing organizations, and international law. Careers and professional life in the legal field. Offered on a graded basis only. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
course_title: The Refugee Experience in France and Italy
full_title: FREN3185W - The Refugee Experience in France and Italy
description: French and Italian culture, migration, global studies, refugees. Legal issues, current events, and cultural representation of vulnerable migrants. Taught in English. [3] (P)

subject: French
description: Development of the novel as a genre in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; its changing social, intellectual, and political context. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: Pre-modern French society through medieval literature and history. Study of the imagined society recreated in modern medieval and Renaissance "faires," films, novels, and video games. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: The themes and art of film in France and the French-speaking world. Offered in French at Vanderbilt in France and in English at Nashville. When offered in English, this course does not count toward the minor, and writing must be done in French to count toward the major. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: The geopolitical, linguistic, and literary dimensions of the notion "La Francophonie." Readings will be chosen from fictional and nonfictional works from Africa, Canada, the Caribbean, countries bordering the Indian Ocean, and Vietnam. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (P) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Major literary works of Haiti, Martinique, Guadeloupe, and French Guyana. Historical, geographic, and cultural context. Comparative approaches to the Hispanic and Anglophone Caribbean. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Critical study of the Francophone press (print, television, radio, internet) in Europe, Africa, Canada, Louisiana, Islands in the Caribbean and Indian Ocean (Madagascar, Seychelles). Current issues in the media. Comparisons with the U.S. press. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
course_title: Popular Music and Social Change in France and the Francophone World
full_title: FREN3332 - Popular Music and Social Change in France and the Francophone World
description: Culture and history. Popular musical production in France, Canada, Haiti, the Caribbean, the Maghreb, and Africa. Granular analyses of musical and lyrical content; how popular music both spearheaded and reflected social issues and change, especially beginning in the 1960s. Prerequisite 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: Literature and society in the reign of Louis XIV. Authors include Mme de Lafayette, La Fontaine, Moli√®re, Pascal, Racine, and Mme de S√©vign√©. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: Major writers of the eighteenth century, including Montesquieu, Voltaire, Rousseau, Diderot; literature of the Revolution. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
course_title: Identity and Family in French & Francophone Culture
full_title: FREN3622 - Identity and Family in French & Francophone Culture
description: Family in relation to identity, history, and memory in France.  Relationship between the individual and the community. "Self-inventing" individuals against families and communities. Key contemporary French and Francophone texts and films. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT) (CORE LA)

subject: French
course_title: Parisian Geographies: Paris in 19th and 20th century Art and Literature
full_title: FREN3634 - Parisian Geographies: Paris in 19th and 20th century Art and Literature
description: The changing physical landscape and cultural significance of Paris in literature, painting, photography, and film of the 19th and 20th centuries. No credit for students who have earned credit for 3891 offered Fall 2018. Prerequisite 2501W. [3] (HCA) (CORE LA)

subject: French
full_title: FREN3730 - The Beat Generation's French Connection
description: The Beats' ties to Paris and to Quebec through French-Canadian Jack Kerouac. Antonin Artaud, Jean Genet, Arthur Rimbaud, and Marquis de Sade. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Content varies according to the needs of the individual student. Primarily designed to cover pertinent material not otherwise available in the regular curriculum. May be repeated for a total of 12 credits over a four-semester period, but students may earn only up to 3 credits per semester of enrollment. [1-3; maximum of 12 credits total for four semesters of FREN 3850] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
description: Under faculty supervision, students intern in public or private organizations, and complete research and readings. Offered on a pass/fail basis only and must be taken concurrently with 3881. Corequisite: 3881. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
course_title: Internship Readings and Research in France
full_title: FREN3881 - Internship Readings and Research in France
description: Under faculty supervision, students intern in public or private organizations, and complete research and readings. Must be taken concurrently with 3880. Corequisite: 3880. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
description: Topics vary. Prerequisite: 2501W. May be repeated for credit more than once if there is no duplication in topic. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course each semester. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
course_title: Special Topics in Communications and Intersections
full_title: FREN3892 - Special Topics in Communications and Intersections
description: Topics vary. Prerequisite: 2501W. May be repeated for credit more than once if there is no duplication in topic. Students may enroll in more than one section of this course each semester. [3] (No AXLE credit)

subject: French
description: The postcolonial Francophone novel of Subsaharan Africa illustrating topics such as tradition and modernity, the identity of Africa, the representation of women, and the ideology of language. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Carnival themes of transgression, the grotesque, feasting, and the "fool." Rabelais to contemporary works. Offered on a graded basis only. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (P)

subject: French
course_title: Emile Zola: From Naturalist Novels to Social Activism
full_title: FREN4027 - Emile Zola: From Naturalist Novels to Social Activism
description: The author's method of researching subject matter and style of writing. "Environmental" influences of violence, prostitution, and alcoholism. The idea of the "public intellectual." Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: Critical readings of representative works organized thematically with emphasis on their contextual and intertextual relationships. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: Religious and ideological terrorism in Francophone contemporary theater (North African and Middle-Eastern dramaturges). Theatrical nature of terrorism; spectacle as predominant motif; analysis of theatrical mise-en-scene.  Cult of martyrdom; notions of sacrifice, shame, duty and honor through recent historical events. [3] (INT)

subject: French
description: Confessions, murder, argumentation, interpretation, and the representation of "the criminal" in literary and legal texts from traditional French writings. Offered on a graded basis only. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (P)

subject: French
course_title: True Crime and Crime Fiction in Nineteenth-Century France
full_title: FREN4233 - True Crime and Crime Fiction in Nineteenth-Century France
description: Representation of crime and criminality in fiction, newspaper reporting, and criminological texts in nineteenth-century France. Memoirs of Vidocq, a notorious criminal-turned-policeman who inspired some of the greatest novelists of the nineteenth-century. Complicated interplay of fact and fiction in crime. Serves as repeat credit for FREN 3891-01  offered Fall 2022 and Spring 2020. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
course_title: Dangerous Bodies: Women in 19th Century Art and Literature
full_title: FREN4234 - Dangerous Bodies: Women in 19th Century Art and Literature
description: Nineteenth century novels and poetry with an emphasis on representations of the female body. Painting and photography. No credit for students who have earned credit for 3891 offered Fall 2017. Prerequisite: French 2501W. [3] (HCA)

subject: French
description: Feminist themes in twentieth-century French literature and criticism. Authors include Beauvoir, Duras, Sarraute, Irigaray, Cixous. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (P) (CORE LA)

subject: French
full_title: FREN4430 - Minority Issues & Immigration in France
description: Study of waves of immigration in France from 1850 to the present through historical accounts and cultural manifestations; exploring the influx and challenges of European, Vietnamese, North African, and Sub-Saharan immigrants, as well as the impact of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on minority issues of political, social, and religious dimensions in French context. Prerequisite: FREN 2501W. [3] (P)

subject: French
description: From Montaigne to Sartre and beyond. Critical discourses and major philosophical texts. Prerequisite: 2501W. [3] (HCA) (CORE LA)

subject: French
description: No description available

subject: French
description: No description available

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Topics vary. General Elective credit only. [1] (No AXLE credit)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Independent learning and inquiry in an environment in which students can express knowledge and defend opinions through intensive class discussion, oral presentations, and written expression. May be repeated for credit once if there is no duplication of topic, but students may earn only up to 3 credits in any 1111 course per semester of enrollment. [3; maximum of 6 credits total for all semesters of 1111] (AXLE credit category varies by section)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Sex and Gender in Everyday Life
full_title: GSS1150 - Sex and Gender in Everyday Life
description: Sex and gender roles in culture and society. Gender, race, and class. Women and men in literature, art, culture, politics, institutions. Repeat credit for students who have completed 1150W. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Sex and Gender in Everyday Life
full_title: GSS1150W - Sex and Gender in Everyday Life
description: Sex and gender roles in culture and society. Gender, race, and class. Women and men in literature, art, culture, politics, institutions. Repeat credit for students who have completed 1150. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Historical, cultural, and social contexts of sexual diversity, discrimination, and sexual violence. Understanding the centrality of sexuality to identity; challenging harmful modes of sexual expression; developing critical awareness of sex and sexuality. [3] (P) (CORE A, E) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Historical, cultural, and social contexts of sexual diversity, discrimination, and sexual violence. Understanding the centrality of sexuality to identity; challenging harmful modes of sexual expression; developing critical awareness of sex and sexuality. Repeat credit for students who have completed 1160. [3] (P) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Images of gender and race; techniques, sound, lighting, cinematography in relation in gender. Prerequisite: 1150 or 1150W or 1160. [3] (US)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Gender and urban processes; spatial and social organization of the city. Geography of gender relations. Gender, sex, race/ethnicity, class, and ability as spatial power relations. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Another World is Possible: Feminist Futures
full_title: GSS2222W - Another World is Possible: Feminist Futures
description: Political activism, community-building, and artistic expression forging visions of the future. Structures that uphold systems of oppression. Perceptions and critical assumptions of the future as natural, predetermined, or immovable. Feminism, colonialism, racial capitalism, policing and abolition, environmental justice, and borders and mobility. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Intersectional ecofeminism; climate fiction, films, and contemporary activism; climate change, resource inequality, and systemic oppression; legacies of colonialism, racial capitalism, and hetero-patriarchy; our present climate crisis and its global complex inequalities. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Gender differentiation in popular culture and mass-market products. Portrayal of women in movies, print, music, and the Internet. The sources and effects of these portrayals. Women as both consumers and the consumed. Prerequisite: 1150 or 1150W or 1160. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Judaism and feminism. Women in the Hebrew Bible, Jewish law, natural philosophy, and history. Case studies in Jewish medieval and modern contexts; problems of assimilation and cultural specificity in modern society. [3] (INT)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Status and experiences of Jewish and non-Jewish women living in Israel. Religion and the law; Jewish and non-Jewish minorities; women and the military; women's health; violence against women; the Palestinian/Israeli conflict. [3] (INT)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Women in Judaism II: Recent Jewish Feminism
full_title: GSS2236 - Women in Judaism II: Recent Jewish Feminism
description: Twenty-first century developments in Jewish thought regarding gender, sex, and sexuality. Methodologies by which scholars grapple with regnant, "traditional" Jewish sources and norms of interpretation and practice. Race, class, and disability; role of gender in Jewish ethics, theology, ritual, ethnography, and textual interpretation. Prerequisite: GSS 2234 or JS 2710W. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: How culture influences women's health, body image, self esteem. Issues include fertility control and child bearing, medical innovations to detect disease, alternative therapies, psychological well-being, sexuality, physical and sexual abuse. Impact of politics on health options for women. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Examination of classical and contemporary representations of women who kill. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
full_title: GSS2243 - Sociologies of Men and Masculinity
description: Traditional and emerging perspectives on masculinity and male gender-roles. Emphasis on relationship between social forces and males' everyday experiences across the life-span. Prerequisite: 1150 or 1150W or 1160. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
full_title: GSS2244 - The Body, Culture, and Feminism
description: The body as a cultural, social, and historical construction. Western culture and narratives of "normalcy" and their impact on identity and representation. Body image and eating disorders. Cultural politics of size, weight, and shape. Disability. Cosmetic surgery. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Gendered, colonial, and racialized articulations of spaces. Bodies and land as sites of theorizing. Analysis of global and transnational locales. Indigenous feminist theories. Gender in concepts of development, environment, colonialism, migration,  mobility and war, climate change, and globalization. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Novels challenged, censored, or banned from schools, colleges, and libraries in the United States. Those considered politically subversive, socially disruptive, sexually explicit, or offensive in historical, cultural, and political contexts.  Intellectual freedom, censorship, and advocacy in relation to banned books. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Gentrification; creative and ecological cities; queer economies; racial and ethnic aspects of gentrification; suburbanization of poverty; the contemporary housing crisis. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Women and Humor in the Age of Television
full_title: GSS2249 - Women and Humor in the Age of Television
description: The period 1950 to present. Television variety shows, sitcoms, and stand-up comedy as media for promoting women's humor and feminism. Comedy as a means of dealing with difficult personal and social issues. Prerequisite: 1150 or 1150W or 1160. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
full_title: GSS2252 - Sex and Scandals in Literature
description: From the eighteenth century to the present. Women's and men's disorderly conduct as represented in literary texts. Charlotte Rowson, Kate Chopin, Edith Wharton, Henry James, and Toni Morrison. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: From the nineteenth century to the present. Feminist ideas and ideals as represented in literary texts. Kate Chopin, Edith Wharton, Virginia Woolf, Alice Walker, and Margaret Atwood. [3] (HCA) (CORE A, E) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: From the nineteenth century to the present. How girls' and women's intimacies are monitored and policed in literature and culture. Impact of race, class, religion, and disability on expression and reception of relationships. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of life-stories as narratives. Strategies of self-representation and interpretation, with particular attention to women. Includes fiction, biography, autobiography, history, ethnography, and the writing of life-story narratives. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2259W. [3] (HCA) (CORE A) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of life-stories as narratives. Strategies of self-representation and interpretation, with particular attention to women. Includes fiction, biography, autobiography, history, ethnography, and the writing of life-story narratives. Repeat credit for students who have completed 2259. [3] (HCA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Cultural analysis of drag performance and histories of drag practice in ancient Greece, Elizabethan and Restoration England, Japan's Edo period, British and American stages 17th-21st centuries. [3] (P)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
full_title: GSS2261 - Staging Women's Stories and Bodies
description: Materiality of storytelling -- physical, sensory, or tangible aspects of how stories are told - in theatre, film, television, digital media, and sports; presentation of women's bodies. [3]

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Religious worldviews connected to moral traditions. Epistemological and ethical systems and their relationship to gender and patriarchy. Social construction of gender; violence against women; feminism; and difference. [3] (P) (CORE E) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
full_title: GSS2267 - Seminar on Gender and Violence
description: In-depth study of violence against women, with a service-learning component in a community setting. Topics include domestic abuse, rape, sexual harassment, pornography, and global violence. Focus on problems and potential solutions, examining violence on a societal, institutional, and individual level, interrogating the "personal as political," and exposing power structures that shape our communities. [3] (P) (CORE B) (LE HFA)

subject: Gender and Sexuality Studies
course_title: Gender, Race, Justice, and the Environment
full_title: GSS2268 - Gender, Race, Justice, and the Environment
